content: How can I help you today?

Well, I’m here because things at home have been really tough. My wife and I have been struggling with our son’s behavioral issues, and it’s putting a huge strain on our marriage. She thinks seeing you might help, but honestly, I’m not sure what to expect from this.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like things have been really difficult for you and your family recently. Managing both your son's behavioral challenges and the strain on your relationship must feel overwhelming at times. It's understandable to feel unsure about what this process can offer, but it's a step toward exploring what might help. How are you holding up through all of this?

I’m honestly not doing great. I feel exhausted all the time, like I’m failing as a husband and father. I don’t know how to help my son, and my wife and I just end up arguing instead of figuring things out. I feel stuck and don’t know where to even start.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy weight right now, and feeling stuck can make it even harder to see a way forward. You're clearly trying to be there for your son and your wife, even when it's so challenging. That shows how much you care, even though it might not feel like enough to you right now. What do you think is at the root of feeling this way—like you're failing as a husband and father?

It’s just that no matter what I do, it feels like it’s not enough. I can’t seem to help my son with what he’s going through, and I know it’s wearing on my wife too. I feel like I should have the answers, but I just don’t, and that makes me feel like I’m letting everyone down.

You're holding yourself to a really high standard, wanting to have all the answers and fix everything for your family. It sounds like you deeply value being a supportive father and husband, but not knowing how can leave you feeling powerless and guilty. You're navigating a tough situation, and it's okay not to have it all figured out. How do you think your wife sees the effort you've been putting in?

I don’t know. She says she appreciates me, but at the same time, we’re arguing so much lately, and I can tell how frustrated she is. It makes me feel like no matter how hard I try, it’s not good enough. I just want us to be okay again, but I don’t know how to get there.

It sounds like you really care about your wife and want to strengthen your relationship, even though the challenges with your son are adding a lot of pressure. You're trying so hard, yet feeling like your efforts don't seem to bring the results you're hoping for. That longing for things to be "okay again" reflects how much you value your family and the desire for connection. What would "okay again" look like for you and your wife?

For me, "okay again" would mean that my wife and I are on the same page, working as a team instead of arguing all the time. It would mean feeling like we're connecting again, like we’re supporting each other instead of just being stressed and exhausted. I miss when we could talk without it turning into a fight.

You miss that sense of teamwork and connection with your wife—the feeling of supporting and understanding each other without the weight of constant conflict. Wanting to rebuild that bond shows how much you value your relationship and your ability to navigate challenges together. What steps do you feel could help you and your wife move toward that place of shared support and understanding?

I’m not really sure. It feels like we don’t even know how to talk to each other anymore without everything turning into an argument. Maybe if we could figure out how to actually communicate and listen to each other better, it would help, but I don’t know how to even start. Right now, it just feels like a cycle we can’t break.

That cycle of arguments and miscommunication must feel frustrating and draining, especially since you want so badly to rebuild that connection. Thinking about communication and listening as a starting point is thoughtful—it shows you’re open to change and searching for ways to improve together. Have you had moments where communication with your wife felt more effective or positive in the past? What do you think made those moments work?

I guess in the past, when things were better, we used to make more time to actually sit and talk about stuff, not just react or argue. We’d actually listen to each other instead of just waiting to respond. Maybe we were less stressed back then, or maybe we just had more patience for each other. I don’t know. It feels so far away now.

It sounds like those moments of listening and patience really made a difference when things felt more connected between you two. That balance of being able to talk without reacting or arguing seemed to cultivate understanding and calm, which maybe felt easier when the stress was lower. While it might feel far away now, reflecting on those past strengths shows that you and your wife have had the ability to work well together. What do you think might help recapture even small pieces of that connection?

Maybe just finding small ways to talk again that aren’t about the hard stuff all the time, or setting aside time where we can focus on each other without the kids around. I know it’s hard because we’re both so tired and stretched thin, but even one good conversation could maybe make a difference. It’s just hard to get started, you know?

It makes sense that even one good conversation could feel like a turning point—a chance to reconnect in a small way and build from there. Finding time to focus on each other amidst all the stress and exhaustion is a thoughtful idea, even though it’s not easy. You’re showing a lot of hope that positive change, even if small, is possible. What kind of conversation do you think would feel easiest or most meaningful for you and your wife to start with?

Maybe something simple, like how we’re feeling or something good that happened recently—just a conversation where we’re not blaming or criticizing, but really listening to each other. I think that would help us feel closer, even if it’s just for a little while. I just want to feel like we're on the same side again.

That’s a really thoughtful approach—starting with a simpler, positive conversation where you can focus on feelings or good moments without blame or criticism. It sounds like reconnecting on that level could remind both of you that you’re still on the same side, working through this together. You’re showing a lot of care and a desire for connection. Would you like support in thinking about how to make that kind of conversation happen?
I think I’d like that, yeah. Maybe some help figuring out how to start the conversation or even what to say so it doesn’t spiral into something negative again. I want to get it right this time.

That willingness to approach the conversation with care and intention says a lot about how committed you are to strengthening your relationship. Setting the tone early might really help. Would it be okay to explore ideas together about how to open the conversation and handle those moments where things could turn negative?
